item.title: Biden Issues New Order to Block Chinese Investment in Technology in the U.S.
item.description: The move, which is bound to heighten tensions with Beijing, is designed to focus on specific types of transactions that would give a foreign power access to key technologies.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.category: Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS)
item.media:credit: Patrick T. Fallon/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A humanoid robot at the Consumer Electronics Show in January in Las Vegas. The order will have an impact on microelectronics, artificial intelligence, biotechnology and more.

item.title: Tentative Deal to Avoid Rail Strike Is Reached, Biden Announces
item.description: President Biden praised the agreement as a ‘big win’ for workers and the rail companies.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley
item.media:credit: Dustin Chambers for The New York Times
item.media:description: Freight rail companies and unions representing tens of thousands of workers reached a tentative agreement on Thursday.

item.title: Railroad Workers Point to Punishing Schedules as Cause of Strike
item.description: Employees say the inflexibility of scheduling upended their personal lives. The companies say they maintained service while using fewer resources.
item.dc:creator: Noam Scheiber and Niraj Chokshi
item.media:credit: Dustin Chambers for The New York Times
item.media:description: Freight trains in Atlanta on Thursday. Unions said a tentative contract agreement addressed concerns about time off for medical reasons.

item.title: Roger Federer Says He Will Retire From Tennis
item.description: Federer, who won 20 Grand Slam singles titles, said injuries and surgeries had taken their toll on his body. His final competitive matches will be next week in London.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Clarey
item.media:credit: Ben Solomon for The New York Times

item.title: Florida Flies 2 Planeloads of Migrants to Martha’s Vineyard
item.description: The moneyed summer resort became an unlikely arena in the fight over illegal immigration. Republican states have bused thousands of migrants to New York and Washington.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei, Remy Tumin and Eliza Fawcett
item.media:credit: Ray Ewing/The Vineyard Gazette
item.media:description: Migrants and local officials at St. Andrew’s Episcopal Church in Edgartown, Mass., on Martha’s Vineyard, on Wednesday.

item.title: NY Attorney General May Sue Trump After Rejecting Settlement Offer
item.description: The attorney general, Letitia James, is also considering suing at least one of the former president’s adult children as part of her Trump Organization inquiry.
item.dc:creator: Ben Protess, Jonah E. Bromwich and William K. Rashbaum
item.media:credit: Emil Lippe for The New York Times
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump’s family business could face stiff financial and operational penalties after a trial.

item.title: 5 Russian Bullets Dashed an Opera Singer’s Dreams. Then He Reclaimed His Voice.
item.description: While on a rescue mission in Ukraine, Sergiy Ivanchuk was shot in the lungs, apparently ending his chance at opera stardom. His recovery is a marvel of medicine, chance and his own spirit.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:credit: Lena Mucha for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sergiy Ivanchuk, a Ukrainian opera singer, spent months in the hospital after he was shot trying to save civilians fleeing Kharkiv.

item.title: Mortgage Rates Jump Above 6% for First Time Since 2008
item.description: Mortgage rates have been on the rise since the start of the year as the Federal Reserve affirmed its commitment to tame soaring inflation.
item.dc:creator: Tara Siegel Bernard
item.category: Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp (Freddie Mac)
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: The Search for Intelligent Life Is About to Get a Lot More Interesting
item.description: There are an estimated 100 billion galaxies in the universe, home to an unimaginable abundance of planets. And now there are new ways to spot signs of life on them.
item.dc:creator: Jon Gertner

item.title: Thousands Join ‘The Queue’ to See Queen Elizabeth Lying in State
item.description: Thousands of people waited in line — a very long line — to pay homage at the coffin of Queen Elizabeth II, who will lie in state until her funeral on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: The line to see Queen Elizabeth II lying in state in London crossed the River Thames and snaked for miles along the South Bank.

item.title: Mexico Arrests Army General Linked to Disappearance of 43 Students
item.description: A top military officer suspected of ordering the killing of at least six of the students who disappeared in 2014 has been arrested, the latest in a string of high-profile arrests.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Lopez
item.media:credit: Rodrigo Arangua/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A memorial to the 43 missing students in Mexico City last month.

item.title: Despite Years of Criticism, the US News College Rankings Live On
item.description: Columbia University skidded to No. 18, suggesting that the ratings may be flawed and easily manipulated. But for many families, the list is a marker of prestige.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Saul
item.media:credit: Ting Shen for The New York Times

item.title: There’s Terrific News About the New Covid Boosters, but Few Are Hearing It
item.description: These updated vaccines are more protective, and could fight future variants and help stave off long Covid.
item.dc:creator: Zeynep Tufekci
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: The Transcendent Power of Walking
item.description: Walking in my neighborhood taught me what running wild in the mountains couldn’t.
item.dc:creator: Francis Sanzaro
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times

item.title: Britain 3, America 0
item.description: A third woman is now leading Britain. The U.S. has had, um ....
item.dc:creator: Gail Collins
item.media:credit: Samuel Corum for The New York Times

item.title: Herschel Walker Tests the Importance of ‘Candidate Quality’
item.description: If he babbles his way to a win, we all lose.
item.dc:creator: Frank Bruni
item.media:credit: Ben Wiseman

item.title: Lindsey Graham’s Unbelievably Cruel Abortion Ban
item.description: Either he doesn’t know how pregnancy works, or he doesn’t care.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Goldberg
item.media:credit: Damon Winter/The New York Times

item.title: The Space Between Brain Death and Organ Donation
item.description: An I.C.U. doctor offers a better understanding of brain death.
item.dc:creator: Daniela J. Lamas
item.media:credit: Emiliano Ponzi

item.title: What School Anxiety Dreams Teach Us About Ourselves
item.description: Why we keep having school anxiety dreams, and what they may mean.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Grose
item.media:credit: Eleanor Davis

item.title: Apostle of Black Power
item.description: I’ve urged Black people to reverse the Great Migration and move to the South. Who’s with me?
item.dc:creator: Charles M. Blow
item.category: The Devil You Know: A Black Power Manifesto (Book)
item.media:credit: Jose Luis Magana/Associated Press

item.title: The Fog of San Francisco
item.description: It’s a life force, with an uncertain future.
item.dc:creator: John Branch
item.media:credit: Nina Riggio for The New York Times

item.title: Could a National Abortion Ban Save Republicans?
item.description: An effort by Senator Lindsey Graham to mend a rift in his party seems to have backfired.
item.dc:creator: Michael Barbaro, Nina Feldman, Luke Vander Ploeg, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Patricia Willens, Chelsea Daniel, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
item.category: Dobbs v Jackson Women's Health Organization (Supreme Court Decision)
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Lindsey Graham, right, His proposal for an abortion ban includes exceptions for rape, incest and the life or physical health of the mother.

item.title: Strong Women, Madwomen, Mob Women
item.description: Our critic recommends old and new books.
item.dc:creator: Molly Young

item.title: Queen Elizabeth, and the Power and Limitations of Inspiring Women
item.description: Changing minds can be powerful, but history shows that changing societies takes more.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Piccadilly Circus in central London on Thursday.

item.title: FDA’s Drug Industry Fees Fuel Concerns Over Influence
item.description: The pharmaceutical industry finances about 75 percent of the agency’s drug division, through a controversial program that Congress must reauthorize by the end of this month.
item.dc:creator: Christina Jewett
item.category: Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America
item.media:credit: George Frey/Getty Images
item.media:description: Funding from the pharmaceutical industry alone has become so dominant that last year it accounted for $1.1 billion of the F.D.A.’s drug division budget.

item.title: Can ‘the Merge’ Save Crypto?
item.description: Many fans think it will. But it might end up creating some new problems.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Roose
item.media:credit: Sarah Pabst for The New York Times

item.title: Man Tells of Losing His Arm to an Alligator, Followed by Days Lost in a Swamp
item.description: Eric Merda meant to go exploring, but ended up in what he described as a nightmare survival story.
item.dc:creator: April Rubin

item.title: How to Prevent Common Exercise Injuries
item.description: Here are the four exercises you’re most at risk of doing wrong — and what can keep you safe.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Fairbank

item.title: Gravel Biking is Getting Popular. Here’s How to Start.
item.description: A faster bicycle design with thicker tires is allowing cyclists to explore America’s 2.2 million miles of Here’s what you need to know about this new sport.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Singleton
item.media:credit: Alex Goodlett for The New York Times

item.title: How to Motivate Yourself to Exercise
item.description: Bundle your incentives. Be flexible. Get some support. Here’s how to get — and stay — motivated.
item.dc:creator: Christie Aschwanden
item.media:credit: Keith E. Morrison for The New York Times

item.title: A Full-Body Strength Training Workout at Home
item.description: If you’re willing to be creative, a set of elastic bands can be as effective as a gym full of weights.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Marder
item.media:credit: Cayce Clifford for The New York Times
item.media:description: In addition to resistance training, exercise bands can take the edge off of body weight exercises, like pull-ups. But trainers like Vanessa Liu warn against becoming too dependent on them.

item.title: Walking May Prevent New Knee Pain for Some, Study Suggests
item.description: Encouraging new research suggests walking could help prevent new bouts of knee pain in people with osteoarthritis.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum
item.media:credit: Getty Images
